poem:
"Epitaph for a Flickering Star"

M Emmet Walsh, a dusky beam,
through celluloid silver screens he'd gleam.
Adieu to life's ephemeral scene,
where leads were plays, he was the dream.

Loren Visser's measured glance,
portrayed a tale in single glance.
A film's soul spelled in his dance,
paused final reel, life's grim romance.

Never in spotlight's glaring glare,
but in every scene, Walsh was there.
Lights faded now, chair sits bare,
yet his nuanced echo lingers in the air.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "M Emmet Walsh obituary M Emmet Walsh, who has died aged 88, was one of the few character actors who could be pivotal, if not key, to almost every film he was in. His ability to define any role could tell the audience more about what they were seeing than all the leads put together. This was literally true of the role for which he became famous, as the private detective Loren Visser in the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
